awd_titl_txt: RoL: EAGER: DESYN-C3: Programmable control of metabolism in synthetic cells using intrinsically disordered proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Almost all proteins have a specific three-dimensional structure that maintains its specific activity in the cell. One class of proteins do not. They are referred to as intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs). Their role in the cell appears to be to spontaneously associate with other proteins and activate them collectively. This is an important function to include in the design of a synthetic cell. This project will explore how IDPs interact with other proteins and with DNA and RNA. Of particular interest is how those interactions affect the regulation of gene expression and cell metabolism. Dysfunctional interactions are linked to neurodegenerative disorders, such as ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease). The results of this project may lead to enhanced treatments and improved outcomes for patients suffering from these diseases. The project will also support training and education of undergraduate and graduate students.  Members of underrepresented groups will take part via science involvement programs. 

This project will develop interactions between IDPs and nucleic acids as a control mechanism for gene expression. The approach will be extended to the regulation of protein synthesis. To accomplish that, IDPs will be modified to bind and sequester mRNA in membrane-free organelles. The IDP-RNA complexes will be designed to be responsive to environmental cues, including protein concentration, temperature and protease activity. They must also bind the target RNA tightly, and release captured RNA for expression on demand. Testing of these concepts will take place in a cell-free protein synthesis system. Transcriptional networks will be augmented with genes that express engineered nucleic acid-binding proteins. Pathways will be created to regulate expression of a simple reporter protein and to build circuits to regulate CRISPR interference systems. Thus, this project will establish a global control mechanism for synthetic cells to adapt their functioning to available environmental resources and cues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project advanced the field of synthetic biology and artificial cells by developing interactions between a special class of proteins that lack specific three-dimensional structure known as intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) and nucleic acids (such as DNA and RNA) as a tool to control mechanisms for gene expression. A project focus has been to develop model artificial cells from microdroplets encapsulating IDP and DNA molecules that spontaneously self-assemble to form “membraneless” organelles through environmental cue such as temperature and concentration. This behavior recapitulates the environmentally responsive assembly of membraneless organelles in living cells, whereby the cell uses IDPs to associate with other proteins and nucleic acids to activate them collectively, for regulation of gene expression and metabolism. Another project focus centered on the development of programmable mechanisms for control of gene expression in cell-free transcription and translation (TXTL) systems based on crude cell extracts from E. coli bacteria. The approach developed in this project has used the expression of complementary RNA strands to remove bound CRISPR proteins from target DNA. Graduate students from underrepresented groups have been trained in synthetic biology research under the auspices of this project, with a particular focus in cell-free synthetic biology and the development of synthetic cell architectures for executing encoded genetic programs.

The intellectual merit of this project includes dynamically activating and deactivating the production of protein products in cell-free systems, which is of practical interest for programmable manufacturing of valuable biomolecules such as biofuels and biopharmaceuticals. New polymer physics was elucidated that can describe the phase diagrams and liquid-liquid phase separation driven assembly behavior of condensed phase IDP-DNA complexes. The broader impact of the project includes tools to better understand dysfunctional interactions between IDPs that are linked to neurodegenerative disorders, such as ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease). The results of this project may lead to enhanced treatments and improved outcomes for patients suffering from these diseases. Broader impacts also include a collaboration with Explora, a hands-on experiential science museum located in Albuquerque, to develop outreach activities that teach core concepts in molecular and synthetic biology that are relevant to the topic areas of this project. A peer-reviewed article that presents these aspects of intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project was published in a special award issue of the journal ACS Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research.
